dialogue: Look at this bar divided into thirds. All three parts are shaded. Why does 3/3 equal 1?

options.text: 3 parts out of 3 total—that's all of them, which is 1 whole
Because we divided something into fourths

correct_answer.context: When all parts are shaded (3 out of 3), that represents the complete whole, which equals 1

success_path_dialogue: Right. All 3 parts out of 3 makes one whole.

steps.dialogue: Not quite. Look at how many parts are shaded and how many parts there are total.
Let's think about this together. The bar is divided into 3 equal parts, and all 3 parts are shaded. When we have all the parts, we have the complete whole. That's why 3/3 equals 1.

Let me walk you through this. Look at the bar—it's divided into 3 equal parts, which is why we're working with thirds. Now notice that all 3 parts are shaded. When we have 3 parts out of 3 total parts, that means we have every single part—nothing is missing. When we have all the parts, we have one complete whole. That's why 3/3 equals 1. When the numerator and denominator are the same, we always have one whole.
